meta.title: Hepatitis A, D, and E virus infection

content:
Introduction

Viral hepatitis is a significant global health burden.  This article focuses on hepatitis A virus (HAV), hepatitis E virus (HEV), and hepatitis D virus (HDV), with hepatitis B virus (HBV) and hepatitis C virus (HCV) discussed extensively in separate articles.



HAV and HEV are nonenveloped, single-stranded RNA viruses transmitted primarily through the fecal-oral route and typically causing acute, self-limited infections.  HDV is a defective, circular RNA virus requiring HBV for replication, and is transmitted mainly through parenteral routes.  It can lead to severe chronic liver disease when superinfecting individuals with chronic HBV infection.

Hepatitis A

Epidemiology and transmission



HAV is a member of the Picornaviridae family, causing an estimated 100 million new hepatitis infections annually (many of which are likely unreported).  The virus is prevalent in areas with poor sanitation and limited access to clean water, with higher incidence rates in Africa, Asia, and Latin America.  Because the virus is shed in the stool, transmission occurs via the fecal-oral route and outbreaks are often linked to unsanitary food (eg, undercooked shellfish) and water supplies.  Settings where hygiene may be suboptimal (eg, daycare centers, homeless shelters) can also contribute to person-to-person spread via the fecal-oral route.  Additional risk groups include international travelers, men who have sex with men (MSM), military personnel deployed to endemic areas, and people who use recreational drugs.

Pathogenesis



HAV crosses the intestinal epithelium after ingestion and reaches the liver via the portal circulation.  It replicates in hepatocytes and Kupffer cells without causing direct cytopathic effects.  The liver injury is primarily immune-mediated, involving cytotoxic T cells targeting infected hepatocytes.  The virus is excreted in bile and shed in feces, with peak infectivity occurring before symptom onset.

Clinical presentation and diagnosis



  • Incubation period:  2-6 weeks (average 4 weeks)
  • Children age <6 are often asymptomatic.  Older children and adults typically experience symptoms that include:
    • Fever, malaise, anorexia
    • Nausea, vomiting
    • Right upper quadrant pain (hepatomegaly is common)
    • Jaundice, dark urine, pale stools
  • Laboratory findings
    • Elevated alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST), often >10 times the upper limit of normal
    • Elevated bilirubin levels and alkaline phosphatase
  • Serology
    • Anti-HAV IgM indicates acute infection.
    • Anti-HAV IgG indicates past infection or immunity.

Complications



HAV infection is generally self-limited with full recovery within 3-6 weeks.  Rare complications include:



  • Fulminant hepatitis (more common in older adults, those with chronic liver disease, and pregnancy)
  • Cholestatic hepatitis (prolonged jaundice, pruritus)
  • Relapsing hepatitis (symptoms return after initial improvement)


Hepatitis A does not usually become chronic.

Management



Supportive care is generally sufficient.  Patients with severe cases (eg, fulminant hepatitis) may require hospitalization.  No antiviral therapy is available.

Prevention



HAV infection can be prevented with good hygiene (eg, handwashing, safe food and water practices) and vaccination.  Preventative vaccination is recommended for:



  • All children at age 1
  • Travelers to endemic areas
  • High-risk individuals such as MSM, chronic liver disease, recreational drug use, occupational risk (eg, food handling)


Postexposure prophylaxis options include HAV vaccination (active immunity) or immunoglobulin (passive immunity) within 2 weeks of exposure.



  • Vaccination is preferred because it offers long-term protection, is more readily available, and is easier to administer.
  • Immunoglobulin is typically administered to individuals with an impaired ability to mount a vaccine response, namely children age <1 and immunocompromised individuals.

Hepatitis E

Epidemiology and transmission



HEV is a member of the Hepeviridae family and remains a common cause of acute hepatitis in developing regions (eg, Asia, Africa, Mexico), with an estimated 20 million infections annually.  As with HAV, it is transmitted via the fecal-oral route, most commonly through contaminated water, but it can also be transmitted through ingestion of undercooked meat (eg, pork).

Pathogenesis



As with HAV, HEV enters the body via ingestion and reaches the liver through the bloodstream.  It replicates within hepatocytes and causes immune-mediated liver injury.  HEV infection during pregnancy can lead to severe fulminant hepatitis, possibly due to hormonal and immune changes affecting viral replication and immune responses.  There is an associated high mortality in infected pregnant women, particularly during the third trimester.

Clinical presentation and diagnosis



  • Incubation period:  2-8 weeks (average 6 weeks)
  • Most patients are asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic.  When present, symptoms are similar to HAV infection (eg, jaundice, anorexia, abdominal pain).
  • Severe disease can be seen in pregnant patients, particularly in the third trimester.
  • Laboratory findings:  Elevated ALT and AST levels
  • Serology
    • Anti-HEV IgM antibodies indicate acute infection.
    • Anti-HEV IgG antibodies indicate past infection or immunity.
    • HEV RNA detection is by PCR, especially in immunocompromised patients in whom serology can be unreliable.

Complications



As with HAV, HEV infection is typically self-limited with full recovery within 3-6 weeks.  Rare complications include:



  • Fulminant hepatitis, usually seen in pregnant patients, with mortality rates up to 25% in the third trimester.  It can also occur in individuals with preexisting liver disease (eg, cirrhosis).
  • Chronic infection can rarely occur in immunosuppressed individuals (eg, organ transplant recipients), leading to persistent infection with risk of cirrhosis.
  • Neurological complications such as Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuralgic amyotrophy, or meningoencephalitis have rarely been described.
  • Extrahepatic manifestations including pancreatitis, renal impairment, or hematologic abnormalities are seen mainly in severe or prolonged cases.

Management



Supportive care is the mainstay of treatment for HEV infection, as most cases are self-limited.  Patients with severe cases, such as fulminant hepatitis or complications during pregnancy, may require hospitalization.  Antiviral therapy is not routinely used, although ribavirin can be used off-label for chronic infection in immunosuppressed patients (contraindicated during pregnancy due to teratogenicity).  Immunosuppressant medications should be reduced or stopped to facilitate viral clearance.

Prevention



HEV infection can be prevented through improved sanitation, access to clean water, and thorough cooking of meat (particularly pork and game).  No widely available vaccine exists outside of China, where an HEV vaccine is licensed but not used globally.  No specific postexposure prophylaxis options exist for HEV.

Hepatitis D

Epidemiology and transmission



HDV is a defective virus belonging to the Deltavirus genus, requiring the hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) from HBV to replicate.  Approximately 15-20 million people are infected with HDV worldwide, with high prevalence in the Mediterranean, Middle East, and parts of Africa and South America.



Transmission routes include:



  • Parenteral exposure (injection drug use with contaminated needles is the most significant transmission route)
  • Sexual contact (unprotected sex, especially among individuals with multiple partners or MSM)
  • Vertical transmission (less common but possible from an infected mother to the newborn)

Pathogenesis



HDV is a small, enveloped RNA virus that does not contain a replicase or RNA polymerase.  Therefore, the virus is completely reliant on host cell machinery for transcription and translation.  HDV can only finish its replication cycle in the setting of HBV infection.  HBV encodes for several envelope proteins (HBsAg) that are used to generate the envelope of HDV.

Clinical presentation and diagnosis



  • Coinfection with HBV:  Both viruses enter hepatocytes simultaneously, leading to acute, often severe, hepatitis.  Symptoms include jaundice, fatigue, abdominal pain, and a serum sickness–like syndrome (eg, fever, rash, joint pain).
  • Superinfection on chronic HBV:  HDV infects an individual with chronic HBV, often resulting in a more aggressive disease.
  • Laboratory findings:  elevated liver enzymes
  • Serology
    • Anti-HDV IgM and IgG antibodies
    • HDV RNA detection confirms active replication.
    • HBsAg is positive, indicating acute or chronic HBV infection (required for HDV infection).

Complications



HDV infection can lead to severe liver disease, especially in the setting of chronic HBV infection.  Complications include:



  • Fulminant hepatitis can occur in patients with acute coinfection but is more common in those with HBV superinfection, leading to rapid liver failure and a high mortality rate.
  • Chronic infection is much more common with HDV superinfection in individuals already chronically infected with HBV.  This complication can accelerate liver disease progression, with a high risk of developing cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma.

Management



Management of HDV is challenging due to the limited antiviral options available.  Treatment of acute infection is supportive but some severe cases may require liver transplantation evaluation.  For chronic hepatitis D, interferon-alpha can be given in high doses over extended periods to suppress HDV replication; however, adverse effects are common and relapse often occurs after discontinuation.  Treatment of concomitant HBV infection should be given if eligible, usually with entecavir or tenofovir (limited effect on HDV).  Other agents (eg, bulevirtide, an HDV entry inhibitor that acts on a receptor shared by HBV and HDV) are being investigated.  In patients with end-stage liver disease or fulminant hepatitis, liver transplantation may be considered.

Prevention



Prevention of HDV is closely linked to controlling HBV, as HDV cannot infect individuals without HBV infection.  Individuals should also be counseled on safe practices (eg, avoid sharing needles, practice safe sex).  No specific postexpsoure prophylaxis exists for HDV.

Summary



Infectious due to hepatitis A virus (HAV), hepatitis E virus (HEV), and hepatitis D virus (HDV) represent significant global health challenges, each with distinct epidemiological patterns, transmission routes, and clinical outcomes.  HAV infection is a preventable disease due to effective vaccination programs, and most cases are self-limited with few complications.  Although similar to hepatitis A in transmission and general outcomes, HEV poses a particular threat to pregnant patients, where it can lead to life-threatening fulminant hepatitis.  In contrast, HDV infection is a unique viral infection that requires coinfection with hepatitis B virus, often resulting in more severe liver disease and posing significant management challenges due to limited treatment options.
